claim: Someone turning 18 in 2025 was born in 2010

supporting.text: Subtracting 18 years from 2025 results in 2007, not 2010.

attacks.text: Subtracting 18 years from 2025 results in 2007, not 2010.
If the person was born in late December 2007, they would still be 17 for most of 2025, turning 18 only at the very end.
The claim specifies 'someone turning 18 in 2025', which implies they reach 18 at some point during the year, not necessarily at the start.
The Gregorian calendar accounts for leap years, so the calculation is exact and does not depend on birth month.

supporting.text: A person born in 2010 would turn 15 in 2025, not 18.

attacks.text: A person born in 2010 would turn 15 in 2025, not 18.
If the person was born on January 1, 2010, they would turn 15 on January 1, 2025, but not 18.
The claim might be considering a different calendar system where the age calculation differs.
Most countries use the Gregorian calendar, making alternative calendar systems highly unlikely for general claims.

supporting.text: The mathematical calculation (2025 - 18 = 2007) directly contradicts the claim.

attacks.text: The mathematical calculation (2025 - 18 = 2007) directly contradicts the claim.
The claim might account for birth dates late in the year, where someone born in late 2007 could still be 17 at the start of 2025 but turn 18 later that year.
Even with late-year birthdays, the claim explicitly states 'born in 2010,' which is a full three years later than 2007.
The claim could be interpreted as a typographical error, where '2010' was intended to be '2007.'
Without explicit evidence of a typo, assuming an error undermines the integrity of the original claim and is speculative.

supporting.text: Birth records and age verification methods would show a discrepancy for someone claiming to be born in 2010 but turning 18 in 2025.

attacks.text: Birth records and age verification methods would show a discrepancy for someone claiming to be born in 2010 but turning 18 in 2025.
Birth records can be falsified or contain errors, leading to incorrect age verification.
Modern age verification methods, such as biometric data and digital records, are highly resistant to falsification.
In some jurisdictions, legal exceptions or special cases may allow for adjusted age records.
Legal exceptions for age adjustments are extremely rare and require substantial evidence, making them unlikely to apply here.
